pros: Competitive pay, friendly staff, benefits, approachable management
cons: 90 days until you can access PTO

job_title: BHT-behavioral Health Tech in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Great people, great culture. I enjoy going to work most days
cons: It would be nice to have training refreshers quarterly

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Phoenix, AZ
pros: I really enjoyed my coworkers and the 3 12 hour shifts were nice. 4 days off a week was great! Pay was appropriate for what I signed up for.
cons: Sometimes you’ll be understaffed for the types of patients on the floor. Too many patients needing higher care of staff but not enough staff to go around. The staff don’t take the job as serious as the should.

pros: As much overtime as you want
cons: The most unsafe staffing situations I've ever been exposed to. None of the policies regarding attendance and punctuality are adhered to whatsoever. Staff are allowed to call in constantly, even no call no show, with zero consequences, and the hard-working staff that always shows up are the ones left to deal with it and work short all the time. Inappropriate admissions constantly, even with unsafe staffing conditions, which led to sentinel events. No support from senior leadership. I would honestly leave nursing altogether if I had to choose between going back to HBH or not nursing anymore....it was THAT bad. For any employee who legitimately cares for the patient and other staff, you can't win in this place. I felt conflicted daily as I couldn't stand behind the care that was being provided for patients, nor did I feel the staff was appreciated in the least. Sad that there are not better options for patients in the mental health setting.

pros: Pay is decent Meaningful work
cons: Leadership Unethical practices Unsafe working conditions Nepetism Overworked Under appreciated

pros: Coworkers were always trying to help
cons: Leadership was non existent, they couldn’t tel their head for their tail.

pros: Nice facility, parking garage in city
cons: Administration is primarily focused on money and not employee or patients

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in Albuquerque, NM
pros: There is flexible scheduling with plenty of extra shifts to pick up.
cons: Patients can be violent. Often understaffed.

pros: Flexible schedule/PRN availability. Weekend or weekday availability.
cons: No LCSWs providing supervision, no raises, no adjustments for cost of living, they allow inappropriate admissions.

pros: Salary is okay Patients are good
cons: Corporate High turnover Cliques Too much work expected of employees

review_title: Great staff, leadership seems to care
pros: I loved working with the staff at the facility. The corporate office seems to care about the faculty and are willing to jump in when they need to.
cons: High level of stress related to high acuity of patient population.

review_title: Okay once you have the passion drive and motivation
pros:
Some Nice coworkers
Can be fulfilling and rewarding 
Good work and learning experience
cons:
A bit of disorganization 
Low retention rate which sometimes leads to overworking of staff
Can be a high stress environment, understandably 
I may be wrong but you don’t get the sense that the company cares about you
Pay is so-so. Depends on your qualifications

pros: Good pay and people make it bettter.
cons: Varied background and training of staff and workers, also a pro at times.

pros: Experience in the field and what “not to do”
cons: Stressful and a lot of work. Little support.

pros: Good psych experience in journey to licensure.
cons: Staff is constantly changing, including 4 different CEO's over a 4 year period. Lots of employee uncertainty of what will be expected to change with new CEO's or directors, and uncertainty about being able to keep their jobs.

pros: Great place to gain experience
cons: Lack of support from leadership. Professionalism is lacking in certain departments. Short staffed. Hiring warm bodies vs people with a heart and focus for patient care.

review_title: Enjoyed the staff I worked with
pros: helpful staff members and the charting was straight forward. Management is approachable and you know what's expected of you. Atmosphere is friendly and provided with good orientation. Salary was appropriate. Helpful if you are a seasoned worker.
cons: Co-workers frequently didn't show up. A lot of the time we had a pretty heavy load of patients but since the charting is not cumbersome was doable.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Frisco, TX
pros:
-Hours can be flexible if reasonable 
-Learning opportunities
-Colleagues are very friendly! Wonderful people
cons:
-Policy and CEO's kept changing (unstable work dynamic)
-Miscommunication in duties 
-Did a lot more than a normal receptionist (you would do what Intake needed to do).

pros: It's a spot to get in and learn the basics to get you to a better spot. Will make you appreciate your next spot, I'm SURE!
cons: Difficult case load, paper charting (Frisco location), lack of work/life balance.

pros: You have the opportunity to work with some sick patients and the reward of knowing you helped them
cons: Leadership is a joke, they only care about themselves. Rarely see them on the unit helping. They wanted to ignore covid and would penalize you and talk about you if you or a family member was positive. Health benefits and PTO/sick days are basically non existent. The do gooders get punished and those with poor work ethic get away with everything because they are so short staffed.

review_title: Great place to work and gain excellent experience.
pros: Great experience in the mental health field that advances your skills and knowledge.
cons: Can be demanding and requires emotional and intellectual IQ/maturity.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Philadelphia, PA
pros:
Great Benefits
Overtime 
Meet Great People
cons:
Patients are violent 
Overworked

review_title: Unsafe working conditions, lack of staffing, lack of trauma informed care
job_title: Activity Therapist in South Phoenix, AZ
pros: Working in mental health, caring social workers
cons: Horrible staff ratios, poor patient care, inadequately trained staff, poor patient facilities, no EMR all notes completed and filed by hand for social work

pros: Location, benefits, and maybe pay
cons: You feel bad for the patients because we never have any supplies, and our equipment is always broken. Patients wait in admissions for hours until they can get on the unit. Understaffed all the time, and they don't work as teams with other departments. The CULTURE IS HORRIBLE—lots of people who are rude with attitude and don't want to work.

job_title: Lead Behavioral Health Technician in Albuquerque, NM
pros: Good pay and good benefits
cons: Violent patients can be dangerous

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Frisco, TX
pros: 12 hour shifts are good for those with flexible schedules
cons: Support from staff was lacking at times, and turnover is high

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Frisco, TX
pros: Working nights is cool and the staff is great
cons: Not much structure and little training

pros: Awesome place to work with great people
cons: Lots of changes and change in leadership

pros: Nice coworkers, employees are appreciated
cons: understaffed, poor care for patients

job_title: Licensed Clinical Social Worker in Dallas, TX
pros: Good Place to work and benefits
cons: They Don’t Order Stuff until they run out so you are out for awhile

pros: Meeting new ppl is a plus
cons: Everything else at haven sucks

pros: Great nursing and social service staff. I really enjoyed going into work. This hospital is different than other hospitals. Very accommodating to patients. Allowed patients to bring guitars, offered movies all the time, lots of activities for patients and flexible with needs.
cons:
horrible management.
very dangerous work environment. Gladly staff 2 techs for 20+ patients and no issue with leaving 1 tech on unit while other tech leaves to do admission. 
Multiple complaints of being understaffed...took an acute patient off 1:1 because of being short staffed and pt was later found attempting to hang themselves in bathroom. When complained to management again about short staffed was told it was staff attitude that was the problem. Over night staff repeatedly required to stay until 12pm and then asked to come back by 7pm to work another 16+ hour shift. 
Also they somehow have an issue with keeping enough water on unit for pts. An entire weekend went by where pts were told to get water out of sink. This has happened repeatedly...seems like an easy issue to avoid. 
Sometimes I wondered if this hospital was run by mickey mouse (no offense mickey)

pros: It is very rewarding role at Haven to search and connect with healthcare professionals that want to make a difference in people’s lives and their communities.
cons: Like any job, there are times when we may feel a heavy load, but knowing I am helping the team and others makes me very content at the end of the day!

pros: Location, Bonus (If goals are met), Company pays for and contributes to HSA medical plan
cons: A typical day is following up on denied or underpaid behavioral health claims. There is no training. All the resources are NOT available or accessible to complete your work. It is either sink or swim. Your tasks are micromanaged constantly. Director makes unprofessional comments about VP to staff. Director and VP will tell you things verbally but will not put it in writing or a email so they won’t be held accountable. Process and procedures for dept are all over the place, not stable. Absolutely no room for advancement or growth. No investments in employees professional development. VP will hire outside (unqualified) friends for promotions instead of considering internal staff members. Low pay for manual workflow process. Turn over rate is ridiculous! No one in department, besides management, has been there over a year. The turnover rate goes all the way up to the C Suites.

review_title: Comfortable with racial/religious  statements and overworked
pros: location, pay is decent, overall atmosphere
cons: upper management tolerant of blatantly racial statements, aggressive behaviors and attitudes from 1 person.  letting an entire team be at their moods mercy.  driving out  talent and good lower management.  systems are antiquated and facilities  have all the controls despite working in the cooperate office. You are responsible for fixing everyone's mistakes even the BOM and UR person.  the work is entirely too much for 1 person.

pros: Great pay w/ overtime; new leadership (CEO Abby H) seems to be trying to improve relationships/culture/communications; convenient to public transportation & major roadways; small staff in Admissions Dept that were competent
cons:
Re-do the staff-to-patient ratio grid so that there will be less understaffing on shifts
Need late evening housekeeping and early morning housekeepers (to start at 6am)
Unit clerk should also start at 6 am so that the Nursing station is in order when the 7 am staff arrive

pros: The new leadership team is MAKING CHANGES HAPPEN!!!     They are changing the food, remodeling the hospital and improving communication among just a few things and all of these changes are happening so fast!   They aren't stalling and want to see this hospital thrive!   It's a refreshing place to work considering these days!
cons: Just continue to assess the hospital and what the patients want and need - which is already happening!

job_title: Past Senior Leader in Phoenix, AZ
pros: BHT for the most part were good. The Two Dr.'s (brothers) are good.
cons: Dysfunctional family in senior management. Each person played a different role in that dysfunctional family. It is lead by the CEO (interesting title for such a tiny place). The CEO is incapable of leading a group. Supervising maybe yes, directing traffic, telling people what to do etc. she can do. Truly lead...not. There is a reason that primary positions turn over multiple times in a year. Upon my first week, I found out that I was the 4th director in that year.

review_title: New aspiring Leaders beware. A place to kill your career!!!
pros:
Mediocre health insurance coverage is included in benefits package free of charge for corporate employees.  

You get a backpack when you sign on.
cons:
The most back stabbing, secret meeting, smile to your face behavioral health organization in the US. 

Hospital cliques that can call corporate and complain about you and you’ll be removed/replaced without investigation and with no opportunity to address allegations. 

Executive leadership provide no clear measurable goals and cannot be trusted.  All it takes is a few phone calls from front line employees who are being disciplined to have you removed with no opportunity to defend yourself.

pros: It pays okay for the job we are doing and you feel like you are helping people sometimes
cons: Always understaffed, bullied by other staff members, disrespected by nurses, administration takes nothing seriously, people are always reporting what you did instead of letting you know so you could correct it, too much paperwork and not enough patient care.

review_title: Hostile work environment encouraged, patient care not as important as company savings
job_title: Psychiatric Registered Nurse in Albuquerque, NM
pros: If there is absolutely nowhere else on earth to work
cons: Almost all of management is unaccountably hostile to floor staff, from the lowest to highest rung - those that were ethical and kind did not last long.

pros: Great staff, even when there aren't enough of them to do the job!
cons: High patient ratios for psychiatric care, very unprofessional and unsupportive management.  Several no call no shows from nurses each week, only to have no consequences from management. Poor work ethics by some staff, as supported fully by lousy management. Truly a place to be if you want to be in court defending your license!!!

pros: New CEO and other Directors which have made a huge improvement with staff morale. Excited to see more improvements and positivity from these leaders.
cons: Needed changes are happening which requires a large amount of training and education to keep up. The changes are positive and much needed to serve this community.

job_title: Behavioral Health Technician in Frisco, TX
pros: No pros to this place at all
cons:
Toxic work environment with gossip and lack of consistency on policies.
No security guards and they don’t care whether you’re safe or not. They will put small women on a floor with large, heavy, aggressive men. I was in several dangerous situations. Patients eloped due to staff leaving unit door open. Many times they leave one BHT to over 20+ patients. You will be completely overworked with way too many patients than is safe, but if anything happens, you will be blamed. Don’t expect the RN’s to help because they definitely won’t. They don’t cover boards or rounds. Don’t expect to take your breaks or lunch either. You’re so overworked that it’s almost impossible to have time to or find someone to relieve you. Not to mention you only get a 30 min lunch for a 12 hour shift. You’re supposed to get two 15 min breaks in addition, but they won’t happen. They do not care about you whatsoever. 
Run poorly by management. Staff, management, CEO, BHT’s are always quitting. Staff is always frustrated. 
Terrible communication.
Short-staffed all the time. If you really want to work here, keep your head down, show up, shut up, and don’t complain about a thing. Management doesn’t care and they’ll just make you look bad for speaking up.
Unable to leave shift on time due to being short staffed or people not showing up to relieve you. 
Terrible retirement benefits.
Your feedback or communication about issues does not matter. You will get ignored and overlooked. If you communicate any issues to management, they will tell you that you have a bad attitude, or don’t like how you’re acting, are unprofessional, or straight up ignore you. 
They don’t always honor bonuses for you picking up shifts. You have to keep all record of text messages or contact with managers otherwise they will screw you over. Scheduling is a game you have to learn how to play. They’ll make you switch shifts to accommodate their staffing with the threat to cancel on your scheduled days. If you just let them cancel you, then pick up the shift on the day they need, you’ll get the bonus. But if you switch, they will not. Some people go from Full-Time to PRN just to pick up their own shifts with bonuses and make more money. Expect to be treated poorly by management and your co-workers. I’ve never felt more unappreciated, unvalued, and disrespected in a work place than I do here. Overall, don’t work here. It’s the worst place I have ever worked. Save yourself the frustration.

review_title: Ethics are questionable. Very blatant about profit more important than patients. Treats their workers like machines.
pros: I guess it pays okay
cons:
No EMR
Constantly short-staffed to a point where patients are allowed to care for each other if needed
Admin pressures staff to discharge patients by 9am for “financial reasons”
Admin pressures staff to discharge dementia patients to the streets
No CEUs

review_title: Good pay high pt load high turn over
pros:
12 hr shifts
Good pay
Nice renovated facility
Good accrual rate for PTO
cons:
Poor staffing ratios
High staff turn over due to burn out
While taking care of a large assignment of dual diagnosis patients, typical day shift sees 6 discharged and admissions per day that have to be completed as well as normal nursing duties of psychiatric and detoxing patient.

pros: Overall good company and benefits. Employees for the most part are nice!
cons: Employees for the most part are nice but the look of their faces is to worry about it. They are scared of the administration. They overworked you and they don’t care about the wellbeing of you and you don’t have family time at all.

review_title: Best Paying Psychiatric facility in the area
pros: Pay, employees, management doesn't micromanage
cons: Schedule is not flexible. Fixed schedules that you're plotted in when hired. Who does that anymore?

review_title: A revolving door - high turn over in nurses
pros: Wages seem reasonable for the nursing market.
cons:
Did not like the way they treated residents.
Behavioral Techs do not listen and are on their phones when they need to tend to patients.
If you are not in with the nurses they reject you.

pros: Good money and great floor staff
cons: Horrible administration, they don't follow their own policies, extremely unsafe working conditions, horrible admissions process resulting in inappropriate admissions, you will feel unsafe nearly every shift and treated so poorly you will be in disbelief

pros: Location is good depending where you live in DFW.
cons: Staff are constantly overwhelmed by the number of patients that require so much care and supervision. Not enough staff to handle and care for the types of geriatric patients that are admitted.

pros: Friendly and Supportive Therapeutic Staff and Associates
cons: Bad Management, Poor Communication Skills

review_title: Says all the right things, but is worse than other hospitals.
pros: Has a newer facility that hasn't been trashed yet.
cons: Haven says all the right things, about how different they are, but really, they're so  deep in denial about the fact that they are just as bad as the other local hospitals, or worse even, that they won't change.

pros: Can’t think of anything at this point
cons: Poor leadership, cant trust ceo, he’s young and inexperienced.  A patient got staff keys that they left on the unit and escaped. Patient was suicidal and homicidal. Lucky they got him back after 4 days. It was never reported to the state and the employee was permitted to come back after being fired. The catastrophe that this could have been.

pros: Some hard working people in the mix willing to help other staff.
cons: Techs insubordinate towards RNs,  D.O.N. has little interest in staff well being. Hires friends in. Lots of  important things undone shift to shift. Up to 12-15/1 ratio. No security on hand for psych emergencies and violent patient management.

review_title: Great for entry level, no advancement
pros:
The clientele and some of the long term staff
Decent hours
cons:
Poor PTO 
Needs more education and more advancement such as training opportunities or financial support for further schooling. 
Burnout

pros: Good pay and team mates.
cons: Poor communication between upper echelons of corporation and local site.

pros: good staff, good culture, more holistic approach to care
cons: awful administration, rules change every day, no consistency in care

pros: You know what to expect every day. The staff is nice and lets you feel at home quickly.
cons: Was a little understaffed when I worked there.

pros: PAY is really good and co workers are good

SHORT STAFF

pros: Well designed facility, good teamwork

people i worked with (excluding leadership) were great.

pros: Great team mates, compassionate and caring staff. Supportive management!
